channel.title: Bot protection ideas
channel.description:
What are some good ideas for bot protection?
One idea I have made a reality is to log to my server everytime the user opens (not log in) the client. It works pretty cool, It just submits some data to a php page, of which inserts the info into my database to view. Some of the data is the current working directory [code]System.getProperty("user.dir");[/code] which in most cases people don't rename their bot folders. I know they could rename shit to w/e. but it's always good to check for little mistakes like that!
Anyway, what are some ideas you guys have thought of, or done?

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @JUMPHIM JUMPHIM
item.description:
@JUMPHIM wrote:

nacional:

I’m sure if proper anti-botting methods are in place more legit people would play. I for example wouldn’t play legit such a low xp server knowing even if a small group had such a big advantage. And of course there’s always such a group with bots but if the devs wouldn’t even try to stop them I wouldn’t play. I know I can’t speak for everyone but I’m sure many other think the same way.

+2

Read full topic

item.description:
@Jython wrote:

dummiis:

Allatori obfuscator is the way i would to go, to be safe against bots. meh

allatori is easily defeatable

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“RLN, post:35, topic:397359”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=494504.msg3618182#msg3618182 date=1307157657]
Why would you just allow people to bot? Writing a bot would be feasible, just not a completely undetectable one… Also, playing cat and mouse is fun…
[/quote]What purpose does it serve not allowing people to bot at this point? With botting you can guarantee your server will be active and like I said before, there are people who simply wouldn’t play due to not caring to play legit. I understand that allowing botting would be a more liberal stance on the issue, but there seems to be no real point in trying to prevent it as if there is a demand for it, there will be people botting and people writing bots. And your analogy of “cat and mouse” will depend heavily on how much effort the developer of the server puts in. You’re basically setting yourself up for defeat by saying there is a dev active enough to continue setting traps.[/quote]
The purpose is not everyone wants to bot, and some people actually put time into skilling, and don’t want to get owned by bots. Botters don’t make the server active, look at RSC… There were hundreds of botters and like 20 people standing around Draynor/Lumbridge. Also, I’m not the one that’s going to be writing the bot…

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

RLN:

Not to mention it defeats the purpose of being open source, you’d need glue code and a separate revisions for releases.

The data would never be analyzed in the server itself, the server would just log the data, to do whatever we wish with at a later time. So no glue code, no seperate releases, we run the exact same thing that is up on github.

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @IlikeArrays IlikeArrays
item.description:
@IlikeArrays wrote:

botting != active

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:33, topic:397359”][quote author=RLN link=topic=494504.msg3617935#msg3617935 date=1307140890]

Why not just simply implement what Jagex did in RS2? Sending mouse movements from the client to the server, which can then be analyzed any way that they choose. No RSC bots that I’ve ever heard of actually send mouse movements at all, so that immediately kills all of them, and I’m not sure that many people are interested or capable enough to write a bot the ‘right’ way.
[/quote]Implementing mouse movement with biometric detection server-side is basically the same amount of time/effort as making a bot emulate mouse movement. Not only that, but if the server is open source it renders it potentially useless over time if anyone writes the initial framework for a bot. I think just allowing people to bot is the best option here. You’ll probably lose a large portion of the rsc user-base if it ends up truly unfeasible to write a bot for said server.

The server along with mouse movement logging can be open source, the code that analyzes the mouse movements later doesn’t have to be, and it’s not that hard to run some simple analysis on the mouse movements to verify they are indeed sent in the first place, and that they don’t look completely fake.[/quote]

Checking that the ending location is correct is easy. Checking if the mouse is teleporting, and moving in completely straight lines is also easy. Movements that are generated by a decent algorithm, and obey steering law is a bit more complex… You essentially need to find a mistake, an implementation flaw, or another piece of data that they didn’t take into consideration. Alternatively, you can always have a human watch them, which is obviously much more subjective, but people are usually able to ‘outsmart’ bots.

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“RLN, post:31, topic:397359”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=494504.msg3616555#msg3616555 date=1307034946]
Why not just simply implement what Jagex did in RS2? Sending mouse movements from the client to the server, which can then be analyzed any way that they choose. No RSC bots that I’ve ever heard of actually send mouse movements at all, so that immediately kills all of them, and I’m not sure that many people are interested or capable enough to write a bot the ‘right’ way.
[/quote]Implementing mouse movement with biometric detection server-side is basically the same amount of time/effort as making a bot emulate mouse movement. Not only that, but if the server is open source it renders it potentially useless over time if anyone writes the initial framework for a bot. I think just allowing people to bot is the best option here. You’ll probably lose a large portion of the rsc user-base if it ends up truly unfeasible to write a bot for said server.[/quote]
The server along with mouse movement logging can be open source, the code that analyzes the mouse movements later doesn’t have to be, and it’s not that hard to run some simple analysis on the mouse movements to verify they are indeed sent in the first place, and that they don’t look completely fake.

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“RLN, post:31, topic:397359”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=494504.msg3616555#msg3616555 date=1307034946]
Why not just simply implement what Jagex did in RS2? Sending mouse movements from the client to the server, which can then be analyzed any way that they choose. No RSC bots that I’ve ever heard of actually send mouse movements at all, so that immediately kills all of them, and I’m not sure that many people are interested or capable enough to write a bot the ‘right’ way.
[/quote]Implementing mouse movement with biometric detection server-side is basically the same amount of time/effort as making a bot emulate mouse movement. Not only that, but if the server is open source it renders it potentially useless over time if anyone writes the initial framework for a bot. I think just allowing people to bot is the best option here. You’ll probably lose a large portion of the rsc user-base if it ends up truly unfeasible to write a bot for said server.[/quote]

Things like that don’t need to be in the server itself, and can still be private seeing the server just needs to store the data (this is assuming we’re specifically talking about MoparClassic, as most servers don’t release their source while it’s running).

Why would you just allow people to bot? Writing a bot would be feasible, just not a completely undetectable one… Also, playing cat and mouse is fun…

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:28, topic:397359"]The powerbot can be used as a ‘base’ someone could easily modify it to work for RSC. And it could be made to work for all servers.
The amount of botters of the playerbase is pretty big, so selling a bot for 10$ each(limited to one PC), the developer would make lots more than 2k.[/quote]

You’re going to find over 200 people willing to spend $10 on a RSC bot for a specific server? I find it hard to believe, and even if you did, it wouldn’t be much over 2k. Also, making it so that it’s forced to be on one PC is going to be pretty hard…

Furthermore, the mouse moving algorithm used in Powerbot look like that have a flaw in it. I’d have to do some testing, but I’m fairly certain I see a method for detecting it over a decent sample size given the correct info (which can easily be obtained from the client). Even if I’m wrong about there being a flaw in the code, the camera rotation is all done by the scripter, and they have to be extremely careful about how they do it, and I’m sure they’ll fuck up because they’re lazy.

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:28, topic:397359"]The powerbot can be used as a ‘base’ someone could easily modify it to work for RSC. And it could be made to work for all servers.
The amount of botters of the playerbase is pretty big, so selling a bot for 10$ each(limited to one PC), the developer would make lots more than 2k.[/quote]

There are many botting ‘bases’ that can be used, I’ve even made one, but making it work for RSC is much harder than it sounds.

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:25, topic:397359"][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=494504.msg3616571#msg3616571 date=1307036999]

Sorry mopar, but that doesn’t work anymore. See www.powerbot.org, RS2’s population is 90% bots now, which proves that it doesn’t work anymore. People just could take powerbots main core and do bot for RSC.

I suppose you didn’t read what I said. Of course it can be done, it’s done for RS2 all the time, but it will destroy all current RSC bots and it would require substantial dev time to write something similar for RSC. I just don’t see it happening, certainly not to the extent of RSC bots now.
[/quote]
Just wait and see, people will make the bot and then sell it to the botters for fair price. Making the development worth the.[/quote]

Implying there is a developer competent enough that’s going to write a bot that is indistinguishable from a human player, especially when things like mouse movement, and camera orientation are being analyzed. Don’t get me wrong, there are clearly people that can accomplish it, but I highly doubt they’re going to do it just to make a bot for a single RSC server, which will bring in 2k if they’re lucky; the time it’s going to take can be spent working on other things that will bring in much more for the time.

Read full topic

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.description:
@5_1 wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:19, topic:397359”][quote author=BuyMyJunk link=topic=494504.msg3615972#msg3615972 date=1306971060]
Change the packet ids with every client release. Do this at least once a week.
[/quote]

At that point why not change them every login?

Anyway, your ‘bot detection’ should have as little to do with the client itself as possible. ‘Detection’ like tracking mouse movements, positions, etc. would be extremely useful, and a pretty big pain for bot makers to emulate humans.[/quote]
Not even man, just do watch ILikewheelchairs suggested. Best idea yet!

Read full topic

Change the packet ids with every client release. Do this at least once a week.

At that point why not change them every login?

Anyway, your ‘bot detection’ should have as little to do with the client itself as possible. ‘Detection’ like tracking mouse movements, positions, etc. would be extremely useful, and a pretty big pain for bot makers to emulate humans.

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.description:
@5_1 wrote:

[quote=“mapu, post:15, topic:397359”]All you need to do is make them have to do tedious changes to the bot every few days in order for it to work (like changing packet id’s), eventually the botters will get so sick of updating it and no more bots

The only way to stop botting is to increase the difficulty of having a working one, to the point where it takes less effort if you were legit.[/quote]
And then The Enforcer comes out with a bot that auto updates… owners mad

IlikeArrays:

Fatigue

Why are you still alive?

Bot Protection Idea: Do what Tewl did, BAN EVERYONE…

No Serious, fuck bot protection, every single person in the RSC community is\was a botter. Don’t go out of your way to ban a botter.

item.title: Bot protection ideas
item.dc:creator: @mapu mapu
item.description:
@mapu wrote:

All you need to do is make them have to do tedious changes to the bot every few days in order for it to work (like changing packet id’s), eventually the botters will get so sick of updating it and no more bots

The only way to stop botting is to increase the difficulty of having a working one, to the point where it takes less effort if you were legit.

Read full topic
